awd_titl_txt: CRII: AF: The Geometry Behind Logistics - Approximation Algorithms for Real-Time Delivery
awd_abstract_narration:
In the era of instant gratification, consumers expect to receive delivery of goods and services on demand. In an effort to address consumer needs, vendors have adopted routing algorithms with little or no provable guarantee. The algorithms available today are often unreliable and yield higher costs than desired.  There are two major difficulties finding effective solutions. First, in many cases, routing decisions need to be made with partial or no information on future requests. The second challenge is related to processing speed. In current solutions, even if all required information is available in advance, it could take several hours to compute an efficient route making real-time routing almost impossible. This project investigates a new approach for real-time algorithms applicable in routing applications. The idea is to use "straight-line" distance between locations as a proxy for the actual road travel distance to design approximation algorithms.
 
The project considers algorithms for certain geometric optimization problems that arise in logistics with a goal of exploring the possibility of a future unified framework in the logistics space. The PI will combine ideas from different research areas including computational geometry, operations research, and online algorithms. In terms of real-world impact, the public and private sectors can benefit from this research. While private sector companies in package delivery and ground transportation services have a vested interest in algorithms providing low-cost routing solutions, real-time routing solutions could also be useful in various humanitarian and military settings. The military, for example, can utilize such algorithms to route supplies quickly. In the case of natural disasters like floods, it is essential to provide timely access to food and aid for people who may be trapped at various locations. Typically in such settings, information about the places where relief is needed changes dynamically, requiring real-time solutions under uncertainty. Further broader impacts include bringing together young researchers with a computer science background and training them across several mathematical topics in an interdisciplinary research plan. 
 
This project will be the first to study the design of geometric online algorithms that assist in making provably better decisions under uncertainty. There is some empirical evidence to suggest that utilizing geometry helps in arriving at better solutions. The PI will, however, build theoretical foundations to justify the claim. Additionally, this project will initiate the design of exact and approximation algorithms for a large class of practical pick-up and delivery problems that commonly occur in logistics. While there are approximation algorithms for certain routing problems in geometric settings, these approaches do not typically extend to the pick-up and delivery problems. The mathematical techniques designed here will advance our understanding of how geometry can be utilized to optimize algorithms for a broader class of routing problems.

por.por_cntn:
In the era of instant gratification, consumer behavior has shifted towards real-time goods and services and businesses are adjusting their strategy to accommodate these expectations. Providing cost-effective and timely service to its user boils down to finding low-cost routing solutions for the goods and services. There are two major difficulties in finding such real-time low-cost solutions. First, in many cases, routing decisions are made with partial or no information on the future requests. The second difficulty relates to execution time of algorithms. In current solutions, even if all required information in available in advance, it could take several minutes to hours to compute an efficient route, thus making real-time routing almost impossible. In this project, we studied design of algorithms that overcome both these difficulties.

 

Intellectual Merit: We consider the following problems. Suppose there are n servers placed across a city and each server can serve exactly one request. The cost of a server serving a request is equal to the distance between their locations. In this problem, requests arrive one at a time, and when they arrive, we need to irrevocably assign them to a free server. Our objective is to make an assignment with as small a cost as possible. Suppose, at the time of making an assignment, the algorithm knows all the request locations, then the problem becomes the well-known minimum-cost bipartite matching problem. On the other hand, if the algorithm has no information on the future request locations, then the problem is the well-known online bipartite matching problem. We obtain the following results:

1)    For the online bipartite matching problem, we introduced a novel RM-Algorithm which provably has an optimal performance in two well-known request generation models, namely adversarial model and the random arrival model.

2)    For the online bipartite matching problem, the RM-Algorithm is near-optimal for any request sequence, i.e., the performance of RM-Algorithm is provably close to the performance of any algorithm that knows the request locations in advance but is not aware of the arrival order. This is surprising since the RM-Algorithm does not have the knowledge of the request locations.

3)    For the online bipartite matching problem, the RM-Algorithm provides near-optimal performance for the case where servers and requests are located on a line. Our algorithm is the best-known solution for this special case that has been studied for over two decades.

4)    We also consider the minimum-cost bipartite matching problem for certain important classes of graph including planar graphs and H-minor free graphs. For the case of planar graphs, we introduce an  time algorithm improving a 40 year old  time algorithm by Lipton and Tarjan.

5)    For H-minor free graphs, we introduce a new algorithm that finds minimum-cost bipartite matching in  time.

6)    For a closely related k-server problem, we design a simple k-median based algorithm that provides near-optimal competitive ratio in the random arrival request generation model.

The algorithms designed as part of this project have triggered several new directions of research and will continue to produce more results in the coming years. Our techniques and ideas have also resulted in design of new algorithms for several closely related optimization problems that are not directly motivated by real-time logistics, including the well-known minimum weight triangulation problem.

 

Broader Impacts: As part of this project, the PI has designed two new graduate level classes, namely, Online Algorithms and Geometric Optimization. Projects pursued by students as part of these classes resulted in five Master’s thesis and also part of an ongoing Ph.D. thesis. This project also supported two female graduate students who published their research in top theoretical computer science conferences. The PI also integrated classical algorithms for bipartite matching problem as part of the undergraduate and graduate level algorithms class. New algorithms designed as part of this project have been presented at top theoretical computer science conferences.
